metadata.description: Name of the custom connector, if you want to change the default name, make sure to use the same in all FortiWebCloud automation playbooks as well
Enter your FortiWebCloud url for example: api.fortiweb-cloud.com. Do NOT prefix with https:// or http:// etc

uiDefinition.tooltip: API Key starts with Basic <<api key>>

properties.description:
[[concat(parameters('CustomConnectorName'), ' connector provides an API that uses Representational State Transfer (RESTful API) design principles to access and modify the settings of ', parameters('CustomConnectorName'), ' applications.

Note: For better understanding , check https://apidoc.fortiweb-cloud.com/')]

info.title: FortiWebCloud
info.description:
FortiWebCloud connector provides an API that uses Representational State Transfer (RESTful API) design principles to access and modify the settings of FortiWeb applications.

Note: For better understanding , check https://apidoc.fortiweb-cloud.com/

source.name: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel

source.name: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel

metadata.title: Block IP & URL on fortiweb cloud
metadata.description: This Playbook Provides the automation on blocking the suspicious/malicious IP and URL on fortiweb cloud waf
prerequisites: 1. FortiwebCloud Custom Connector needs to be deployed prior to the deployment of this playbook under the same subscription.
2. API key. To get API Key, login into your FortiWeb cloud instance dashboard and navigate to Global --> system settings --> API Key.
postDeployment: 1. Once deployment is complete, you will need to authorize each connection.
2. Navigate to playbook --> API Connections --> Select connections one by one --> Edit API Connection --> (if required) Enter API key or credentials --> Save

metadata.description: Name of the custom connector, if you want to change the default name, make sure to use the same in all FortiWebCloud automation playbooks as well

source.name: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel

metadata.title: Fetch Threat Intel from fortiwebcloud
metadata.description: This playbook provides/updates the threat intel and essential details in comments section of triggered incident so that SOC analysts can directly take corrective measure to stop the attack
prerequisites: 1. FortiwebCloud Custom Connector needs to be deployed prior to the deployment of this playbook under the same subscription.
2. API key. To get API Key, login into your FortiWeb cloud instance dashboard and navigate to Global --> system settings --> API Key.
postDeployment: 1. Once deployment is complete, you will need to authorize each connection.
2. Navigate to playbook --> API Connections --> Select connections one by one --> Edit API Connection --> (if required) Enter API key or credentials --> Save

properties.description: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel data connector with template version 3.0.3

connectorUiConfig.title: Fortinet FortiWeb Web Application Firewall via AMA
connectorUiConfig.descriptionMarkdown: The [fortiweb](https://www.fortinet.com/products/web-application-firewall/fortiweb) data connector provides the capability to ingest Threat Analytics and events into Microsoft Sentinel.

graphQueries.baseQuery:
CommonSecurityLog
 |where (DeviceVendor contains 'Fortinet' and DeviceProduct contains 'Fortiweb') or Computer contains 'Fortiweb' 
 |extend sent_by_ama = column_ifexists('CollectorHostName','')
 |where isnotempty(sent_by_ama)

sampleQueries.query:
Fortiweb
 | where isnotempty(EventType)
    | summarize count() by EventType
 | top 10 by count_

dataTypes.name: CommonSecurityLog (Fortiweb)
dataTypes.lastDataReceivedQuery:
CommonSecurityLog
 |where (DeviceVendor contains 'Fortinet' and DeviceProduct contains 'Fortiweb') or Computer contains 'Fortiweb' 
  |extend sent_by_ama = column_ifexists('CollectorHostName','')
 |where isnotempty(sent_by_ama)
            | summarize Time = max(TimeGenerated)
            | where isnotempty(Time)

value:
CommonSecurityLog
 |where (DeviceVendor contains 'Fortinet' and DeviceProduct contains 'Fortiweb') or Computer contains 'Fortiweb'
  |extend sent_by_ama = column_ifexists('CollectorHostName','')
 |where isnotempty(sent_by_ama)
 | summarize LastLogReceived = max(TimeGenerated)
 | project IsConnected = LastLogReceived > ago(30d)

resourceProvider.permissionsDisplayText: read and write permissions are required.

read permissions to shared keys for the workspace are required. [See the documentation to learn more about workspace keys](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/azure-monitor/platform/agent-windows#obtain-workspace-id-and-key).

customs.description: To collect data from non-Azure VMs, they must have Azure Arc installed and enabled. [Learn more](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/azure-monitor/agents/azure-monitor-agent-install?tabs=ARMAgentPowerShell,PowerShellWindows,PowerShellWindowsArc,CLIWindows,CLIWindowsArc)

Common Event Format (CEF) via AMA and Syslog via AMA data connectors must be installed [Learn more](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/sentinel/connect-cef-ama#open-the-connector-page-and-create-the-dcr)

parameters.title: 1. Kindly follow the steps to configure the data connector

instructionSteps.title: Step A. Configure the Common Event Format (CEF) via AMA data connector
instructionSteps.description:
_Note:- CEF logs are collected only from Linux Agents_

1. Navigate to Microsoft Sentinel workspace ---> configuration ---> Data connector blade .

2. Search for 'Common Event Format (CEF) via AMA' data connector and open it.

3. Check If there is no existing DCR configured to collect required facility of logs, Create a new DCR (Data Collection Rule)

	_Note:- It is recommended to install minimum 1.27 version of AMA agent [Learn more](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/azure-monitor/agents/azure-monitor-agent-manage?tabs=azure-portal ) and ensure there is no duplicate DCR as it can cause log duplicacy_

4. Run the command provided in the CEF via AMA data connector page to configure the CEF collector on the machine

instructionSteps.title: Step B. Forward Common Event Format (CEF) logs to Syslog agent
instructionSteps.description: Set your security solution to send Syslog messages in CEF format to the proxy machine. Make sure you to send the logs to port 514 TCP on the machine's IP address.

instructionSteps.title: Step C. Validate connection
instructionSteps.description:
Follow the instructions to validate your connectivity:

Open Log Analytics to check if the logs are received using the CommonSecurityLog schema.

It may take about 20 minutes until the connection streams data to your workspace.

If the logs are not received, run the following connectivity validation script:

 1. Make sure that you have Python on your machine using the following command: python -version

2. You must have elevated permissions (sudo) on your machine

parameters.label: Run the following command to validate your connectivity:

instructionSteps.description:
Make sure to configure the machine's security according to your organization's security policy


[Learn more >](https://aka.ms/SecureCEF)
instructionSteps.title: 2. Secure your machine

properties.description: Fortiweb Data Parser with template version 3.0.3

properties.query:
CommonSecurityLog
| project-away EventType
| where DeviceVendor =~ 'Fortinet' and DeviceProduct has 'Fortiweb'
| extend EventVendor = 'Fortinet'
| extend EventProduct = 'Fortiweb'
| extend EventSchemaVersion = 0.2
| extend EventCount = 1
| extend DeviceCustomNumber1 = coalesce(column_ifexists("FieldDeviceCustomNumber1", long(null)),DeviceCustomNumber1),
         DeviceCustomNumber2 = coalesce(column_ifexists("FieldDeviceCustomNumber2", long(null)),DeviceCustomNumber2),
         DeviceCustomNumber3 = coalesce(column_ifexists("FieldDeviceCustomNumber3", long(null)),DeviceCustomNumber3),
         ExternalID = coalesce(column_ifexists("ExtID", ""),tostring(ExternalID))
| extend Threatweight = iff(DeviceCustomNumber1Label =~ "threatWeight",DeviceCustomNumber1,long(null))
         ,Length = iff(DeviceCustomNumber2Label =~ "length",DeviceCustomNumber2,long(null))
         ,SignatureID = iff(DeviceCustomNumber3Label =~ "signatureID",DeviceCustomNumber3,long(null))
         ,AppName = iff(DeviceCustomString1Label =~ "appName",DeviceCustomString1,'')
         ,srcCountry = iff(DeviceCustomString2Label =~ "srcCountry",DeviceCustomString2,'')
         ,mainType = iff(DeviceCustomString3Label =~ "mainType",DeviceCustomString3,'')
         ,subType = iff(DeviceCustomString4Label =~ "subType",DeviceCustomString4,'')
         ,ThreatLevel = iff(DeviceCustomString5Label =~ "threatLevel",DeviceCustomString5,'')
         ,owaspTop10 = iff(DeviceCustomString6Label =~ "owaspTop10",DeviceCustomString6,'')
| parse-kv AdditionalExtensions as (cat:string) with (pair_delimiter=';', kv_delimiter='=')
| extend EventEndTime = todatetime(ReceiptTime),
         EventType = coalesce(column_ifexists("DeviceEventCategory", ""),cat)
| project-rename EventProductVersion=DeviceVersion
                , EventOriginalType=DeviceEventClassID
                , EventSeverity=LogSeverity
                , EventMessage=Message
                , DstPortNumber=DestinationPort
                , DstIpAddr=DestinationIP
                , DstDvcHostname=DestinationHostName
                , DstUserName=DestinationUserName
                , DvcIpAddr=DeviceAddress
                , DvcAction=DeviceAction
                , DvcHostname=DeviceName
                , DstMacAddr=DestinationMACAddress
                , NetworkApplicationProtocol=Protocol
                , SrcPortNumber=SourcePort
                , SrcIpAddr=SourceIP
                , SrcMacAddr=SourceMACAddress
                , EventId=ExternalID
                , SrcDvcHostname=SourceHostName
                , EventSubType=Activity
| project-away AdditionalExtensions
            , ReceiptTime
            , cat
            , Device*

CommonSecurityLog
| project-away EventType
| where DeviceVendor =~ 'Fortinet' and DeviceProduct has 'Fortiweb'

         DeviceCustomNumber3 = coalesce(column_ifexists("FieldDeviceCustomNumber3", long(null)),DeviceCustomNumber3),
         ExternalID = coalesce(column_ifexists("ExtID", ""),tostring(ExternalID))
| extend Threatweight = iff(DeviceCustomNumber1Label =~ "threatWeight",DeviceCustomNumber1,long(null))
         ,Length = iff(DeviceCustomNumber2Label =~ "length",DeviceCustomNumber2,long(null))
         ,SignatureID = iff(DeviceCustomNumber3Label =~ "signatureID",DeviceCustomNumber3,long(null))
         ,AppName = iff(DeviceCustomString1Label =~ "appName",DeviceCustomString1,'')
         ,srcCountry = iff(DeviceCustomString2Label =~ "srcCountry",DeviceCustomString2,'')
         ,mainType = iff(DeviceCustomString3Label =~ "mainType",DeviceCustomString3,'')
         ,subType = iff(DeviceCustomString4Label =~ "subType",DeviceCustomString4,'')
         ,ThreatLevel = iff(DeviceCustomString5Label =~ "threatLevel",DeviceCustomString5,'')
         ,owaspTop10 = iff(DeviceCustomString6Label =~ "owaspTop10",DeviceCustomString6,'')
| parse-kv AdditionalExtensions as (cat:string) with (pair_delimiter=';', kv_delimiter='=')
| extend EventEndTime = todatetime(ReceiptTime),
         EventType = coalesce(column_ifexists("DeviceEventCategory", ""),cat)
| project-rename EventProductVersion=DeviceVersion
                , EventOriginalType=DeviceEventClassID
                , EventSeverity=LogSeverity
                , EventMessage=Message
                , DstPortNumber=DestinationPort
                , DstIpAddr=DestinationIP
                , DstDvcHostname=DestinationHostName
                , DstUserName=DestinationUserName
                , DvcIpAddr=DeviceAddress
                , DvcAction=DeviceAction
                , DvcHostname=DeviceName
                , DstMacAddr=DestinationMACAddress
                , NetworkApplicationProtocol=Protocol
                , SrcPortNumber=SourcePort
                , SrcIpAddr=SourceIP
                , SrcMacAddr=SourceMACAddress
                , EventId=ExternalID
                , SrcDvcHostname=SourceHostName
                , EventSubType=Activity
| project-away AdditionalExtensions
            , ReceiptTime
            , cat
            , Device*

source.name: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel

properties.description: Fortiweb - WAF Allowed threat_AnalyticalRules Analytics Rule with template version 3.0.3
Detects WAF "Allowed" action on threat events.
properties.query:
Fortiweb
| where EventType =~ 'Attack'
| where DvcAction =~ 'Allow'
| summarize count() by SrcIpAddr

properties.description: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel Analytics Rule 1

source.name: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel

properties.description: owaspTop10-Threatsyaml_HuntingQueries Hunting Query with template version 3.0.3

properties.query:
let MinCount = 10;
Fortiweb
| where TimeGenerated > ago(24h)
| where isnotempty(owaspTop10)
| summarize owaspCount=count() by owaspTop10,EventSubType , SrcIpAddr
| where owaspCount > MinCount
| extend IP_0_Address = SrcIpAddr

tags.name: description
tags.value: Query searches threats and helps to identify threats matching owaspTop10 vulnerabilities.

properties.description: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel Hunting Query 1

source.name: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel

properties.description: Unexpected Countries_HuntingQueries Hunting Query with template version 3.0.3

properties.query:
let blocked_country = dynamic(['countryname1', 'countryname2']);
Fortiweb
| where srcCountry in (blocked_country)
| where DvcAction !has 'Block'
| summarize count() by SrcIpAddr
| extend IP_0_Address = SrcIpAddr

tags.name: description
tags.value: Query searches requests by country and helps to identify requests coming from unexpected countries.

source.name: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel

properties.displayName: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel
properties.descriptionHtml:
Note: Please refer to the following before installing the solution:

• Review the solution Release Notes

• There may be known issues pertaining to this Solution, please refer to them before installing.

The Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector solution for Microsoft Sentinel provides an automated approach for SecOps analysts to remediate attacks at application level by blocking suspicious IP and URL and also empowers to gather threat intelligence data for malicious IP activity. By leveraging the FortiWeb API, the connector can automate these security operations, tasks using Microsoft Sentinel Playbooks which can dramatically reduce the window that attackers can take advantage of.

For questions about FortiWeb Cloud, please contact Fortinet at azuresales@fortinet.com.

  1. Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF via AMA - This data connector helps in ingesting Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF logs into your Log Analytics Workspace using the new Azure Monitor Agent. Learn more about ingesting using the new Azure Monitor Agent here. Microsoft recommends using this Data Connector.

NOTE: Microsoft recommends installation of Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF via AMA Connector.Legacy connector uses the Log Analytics agent which were deprecated on Aug 31, 2024.. Using MMA and AMA on same machine can cause log duplication and extra ingestion cost more details.

Data Connectors: 1, Parsers: 1, Workbooks: 1, Analytic Rules: 1, Hunting Queries: 2, Custom Azure Logic Apps Connectors: 1, Playbooks: 2

Learn more about Microsoft Sentinel | Learn more about Solutions

source.name: Fortinet FortiWeb Cloud WAF-as-a-Service connector for Microsoft Sentinel
